required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Multicenter, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, 3-parallel-group Comparison Trial to Investigate the Effect of Nalmefene on Alcohol Consumption Reduction in Patients With Alcohol Dependence (Phase 3 Trial)
clinical_study.official_title: A Multicenter, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, 3-parallel-group Comparison Trial to Investigate the Effect of Nalmefene on Alcohol Consumption Reduction in Patients With Alcohol Dependence (Phase 3 Trial)

brief_summary.textblock: The efficacy, safety, and dose-response of nalmefene hydrochloride at 10 mg and 20 mg in patients with alcohol dependence will be evaluated in a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, 3-parallel-group comparative trial. The superiority of nalmefene hydrochloride at 20 mg to placebo will be verified in terms of reduction of alcohol consumption.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in the Number of Heavy Drinking Days (HDDs) From Baseline at Week 12
primary_outcome.description: The number of HDDs is defined as the number of days per month [days/month] with alcohol consumption of > 60 g for males and > 40 g for females

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in the Number of Heavy Drinking Days (HDDs) From Baseline at Week 24
Change in Total Alcohol Consumption (TAC) From Baseline at Week 12
Change in Total Alcohol Consumption (TAC) From Baseline at Week 24
Response Shift Drinking Risk Level (RSDRL) at Week 12
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients with a downward shift in drinking risk level of two categories or more

secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients with a downward shift in drinking risk level of two categories or more

secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients with low or lower drinking risk level

secondary_outcome.measure: Response Low Drinking Risk Level (RLDRL) at Week 24
secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of patients with low or lower drinking risk level
Proportion of patients with a 70% decrease in TAC
Proportion of patients with a 70% decrease in TAC

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in CGI-S From Baseline at Week 12
secondary_outcome.description: The CGI-S scale was used by clinicians when assessing their global impression of a patient's current clinical condition. The investigator or subinvestigator used his/her clinical experience with this patient population to rate the severity of a subject's clinical condition on a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (Normal, not at all ill) to 7 (Among the most extremely ill patients).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in CGI-S From Baseline at Week 24
secondary_outcome.description: The CGI-S scale was used by clinicians when assessing their global impression of a patient's current clinical condition. The investigator or subinvestigator used his/her clinical experience with this patient population to rate the severity of a subject's clinical condition on a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (Normal, not at all ill) to 7 (Among the most extremely ill patients).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in CGI-I From Baseline at Week 12
secondary_outcome.description: The CGI-I scale is used to assess a patient's improvement (or worsening). The investigator or subinvestigator assesses a subject's condition relative to baseline on a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (Very much improved) to 7 (Very much worse).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in CGI-I From Baseline at Week 24
secondary_outcome.description: The CGI-I scale was used to assess a patient's improvement (or worsening). The investigator or subinvestigator assesses a subject's condition relative to baseline on a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (Very much improved) to 7 (Very much worse).

Change in Logarithm Scale in Serum γ-glutamyltransferase From Baseline at Week 24
Change in Logarithm Scale in Serum Alanine Aminotransferase From Baseline at Week 12

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Japanese males and females aged 20 or above who have signed the informed consent form
- The patient has alcohol dependence, diagnosed according to Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th Edition, Text Revision (DSM-IV-TR) and confirmed by Mini-international Neuropsychiatric Interview (M. I. N. I.)
- The patient has a drinking risk level of High or above (> 60 g for men and > 40 g for women) both at the Screening Visit and at the Randomization Visit .
Exclusion Criteria:
- The patient with a current diagnosis or history of substance use disorders (except for alcohol, nicotine, and caffeine), according to DSM-IV-TR and confirmed by M. I. N. I.
- The patient has reported current use of, or has tested positive for, drugs of abuse (opiates, methadone, cocaine, amphetamines, barbiturates) at the screening test

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Safety analysis set, which included all randomized patients who received ≥1 dose of the study medication.

measure.title: Age
Age
Sex: Female, Male
Region of Enrollment
Heavy Drinking Days (HDDs)
measure.description: The number of HDDs was defined as the number of days per month [days/month] with alcohol consumption of > 60 g for males and > 40 g for females.

measure.title: Total Alcohol Consumption (TAC)
measure.description: TAC was defined as mean alcohol consumption per day [g/day] over a 1-month period.

measure.title: Drinking Risk Level (DRL)
measure.description: DRL was defined by the World Health Organization based on average volume of alcohol consumption per Day.

measure.title: Clinical Global Impression – Severity of Illness (CGI-S) score
measure.description: The CGI-S scale was used by clinicians when assessing their global impression of a patient’s current clinical condition. The investigator or subinvestigator used his/her clinical experience with this patient population to rate the severity of a subject’s clinical condition on a 7-point scale ranging from 1 (Normal, not at all ill) to 7 (Among the most extremely ill patients).

measure.title: Serum gamma-glutamyltransferase (γ-GT)
Serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT)

outcome.title: Change in the Number of Heavy Drinking Days (HDDs) From Baseline at Week 12
outcome.description: The number of HDDs is defined as the number of days per month [days/month] with alcohol consumption of > 60 g for males and > 40 g for females
outcome.population: Full analysis set, which included all patients who had data on the number of HDDs at baseline and at ≥1 time point after initiation of the study drug.

measure.title: Change in the Number of Heavy Drinking Days (HDDs) From Baseline at Week 12
measure.description: The number of HDDs is defined as the number of days per month [days/month] with alcohol consumption of > 60 g for males and > 40 g for females
measure.population: Full analysis set, which included all patients who had data on the number of HDDs at baseline and at ≥1 time point after initiation of the study drug.

analysis.non_inferiority_desc: Mixed model for repeated measures (MMRM) with fixed effect of treatment, sex, time point, treatment-by-time point interaction, baseline value, and baseline value-by-time point interaction with an unstructured variance-covariance matrix structure was used.
analysis.p_value_desc: Efficacy of the doses (change from baseline in the number of HDDs vs placebo) was assessed using a closed testing procedure. The 20 mg dose was tested at a 5% level of significance and only if significant, the testing would proceed to the 10 mg dose.

analysis.non_inferiority_desc: Mixed model for repeated measures (MMRM) with fixed effect of treatment, sex, time point, treatment-by-time point interaction, baseline value, and baseline value-by-time point interaction with an unstructured variance-covariance matrix structure was used.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
